sect2.title: Advanced Settings
sect2.para: A few infrequently used settings are available only in the advanced page of the settings dialog. These settings modify the registry directly and you have to know what each of these settings is used for and what it does. Do not modify those settings if you're not sure you need to change those.

listitem.para: You can specify a different location for the Subversion configuration file here. This will affect all TortoiseSVN operations.
Set this to true if you want a dialog to pop up for every command showing the command line of the command.
To add a cache tray icon for the TSVNCache program, set this value to true. This is really only useful for developers as it allows you to terminate the program gracefully.

This can be useful if you use something other than the windows explorer or if you get problems with the context menu displaying correctly. Set this value to false if you don't want TortoiseSVN to not show icons for the shell context menu items. Set this value to true to show the icons again.
If you don't want TortoiseSVN to show icons for the context menus in its dialogs, set this value to false.

The log dialog shows the revision the working copy path is at in bold. But this requires that the log dialog fetches the status of that path. Since for very big working copies this can take a while, you can set this value to false to deactivate this feature.

The status list control which is used in various dialogs (e.g., commit, check-for-modifications, add, revert, ...) uses full row selection (i.e., if you select an entry, the full row is selected, not just the first column). This is fine, but the selected row then also covers the background image on the bottom right, which can look ugly. To disable full row select, set this value to false.
The commit and log dialog style commit messages (see for details). If you don't want to do this, set this value to false.

TortoiseSVN uses accelerators for its explorer context menu entries. Since this can lead to doubled accelerators (e.g. the SVN Commit has the Alt-C accelerator, but so does the Copy entry of explorer). If you don't want or need the accelerators of the TortoiseSVN entries, set this value to false.

As the explorer, TortoiseSVN also shows additional commands if the Shift key is pressed while the context menu is opened. To force TortoiseSVN to always show those extended commands, set this value to true.
If you don't want the explorer to update the status overlays while another TortoiseSVN command is running (e.g. Update, Commit, ...) then set this value to true.

This value contains the URL from which TortoiseSVN tries to download a text file to find out if there are updates available. This might be useful for company admins who don't want their users to update TortoiseSVN until they approve it.

The extra columns the TortoiseSVN adds to the details view in Windows Explorer (Only XP, Vista and later don't support that feature anymore) are normally only active in a working copy. If you want those to be accessible everywhere, not just in working copies, set this value to true.

TortoiseSVN by default allows an update that adds a file but which already exists unversioned in the local working copy (i.e., an update adds a file that already exists but is not under version control). And differences between the newly versioned file and the existing unversioned file are then properly handled, i.e. the file appears as modified. If you rather want TortoiseSVN to create a conflict in such situations, set this value to false.

TortoiseSVN checks whether there's a new version available about once a week. If an updated version is found, the commit dialog shows a link control with that info. If you rather want the old behavior back where a dialog pops up notifying you about the update, set this value to true.
TortoiseSVN checks whether there's a new version available about once a week. If you don't want TortoiseSVN to do this check, set this value to false.
The auto-completion list shown in the commit message editor displays the names of files listed for commit. To also include these names with extensions removed, set this value to true.

When you merge revisions from another branch, and merge tracking information is available, the log messages from the revisions you merge will be collected to make up a commit log message. A pre-defined string is used to separate the individual log messages of the merged revisions. If you prefer, you can set this to a value containing a separator string of your choice.

TortoiseSVN allows you to assign external diff viewer. Most such viewers, however, are not suited for change blaming (), so you might wish to fall back to TortoiseMerge in this case. To do so, set this value to true.
